Leslie and I are horrified by the assassination of Charlie Kirk. We are praying for his family, especially his wife and young children.
 
We strongly condemn political violence in all forms. It has no place in the United States. Our country must be better than this.
 
While we didn't know Charlie personally, it's clear he was a God-fearing man and strong conservative who passionately loved our country.
 
Charlie and I have both tried to listen to those who disagree with us and respond with reason and facts. That’s exactly what we did on our recently completed 15-stop town hall tour. Instead of respectful debate, he was murdered.
 
Due to this rise in political violence, our office will be pausing all public events, including town halls, until further notice. I will not risk the safety of my family, my staff, or my own personal safety because some choose violence over dialogue.

Leslie and I are praying for Charlie Kirk, his family, and the survivors of the shooting in Utah.

Political violence is unacceptable.

It is an honor to represent the constituents of the fourth district of the great state of Missouri. Regardless of where district lines may fall, we will continue to advance the America First agenda, while providing top notch service to ALL constituents no matter their political affiliations.

We have said from the outset this effort is between the White House, Governor Kehoe and the state legislature. Now that the Governor has called for a special session on this matter and reform the ballot initiative petitions process, we stand behind him. I trust Mike Kehoe and our state lawmakers to ensure the conservative values of the majority of Missourians are adequately represented in Congress.

May not always agree, but I'll always listen.

Our senior case worker, Grace Townsend, worked for three months through emails and phone calls to the DOD and the Army to get this Purple Heart to the family. We were proud to play a role in making sure it finally happened.

Staff Sgt Houlihan was wounded on Okinawa, Japan, in 1945. He earned the Purple Heart but NEVER actually received it.  His service records were handed down through the family, and his granddaughter, Michele Betz, discovered the papers for the award and contacted our Congressional office to help.

This National Purple Heart Day, we’d like to share an amazing story. 

About two years ago, we had the honor of a lifetime to present the Purple Heart award to Michelle Betz in recognition of her grandfather, Sgt. Merl Houlihan at Whiteman Air Force Base. https://t.co/osGgJYhMYZ

The turnout today and the huge show of support is a testament to the love the 4th Congressional District has for those who serve.

We recently toured a mental health crisis facility located in Boone County, open to residents 24/7. 

Burrell Behavioral Health Crisis Center (BCC), a subsidiary of Brightli, helps with mental health support, especially for those experiencing housing instability or substance abuse. 

Across the 80 counties, they are providing a mental health footprint for many rural areas, making a significant impact in an underserved market. Their 24-hour care facility connects to a larger behavioral health facility, ensuring that no one in the community is left without support.

Thank you for your great work in #MO-04, BCC!

3M plant is renowned for its global commercial graphics and innovation, embodying the company's ethos of continuous invention.

Our casework team traveled to Jefferson City to meet with both Republican and Democrat state-level counterparts to strengthen relationships and better serve our constituents. It is extremely unfortunate that an elected official feels the need to make up politically motivated lies about our team, who works tirelessly for the constituents of the Fourth District. They do not deserve this.

As a serious legislator, these types of reprehensible lies for relevancy are not only offensive to our team, but they are an embarrassing waste of time that does absolutely nothing to help the great people of Missouri.
The truth is that Rep. David Tyson Smith’s legislative assistant welcomed my team with open arms, smiles, and pleasant conversations. The meeting was full of professionalism and constructive conversations, and nobody ever discussed our public phone number (which is widely published on our website and on various Facebook posts).

After this great meeting, she even took the picture posted below. Does she look “intimidated” to you? No—because this entire claim is a flat-out lie.

Our team would also never say they did not want to help constituents with the VA. On the contrary, they have done an incredible job helping to serve our constituents and they have worked diligently to deliver real results for casework claims. I urge the left to stop the partisan political games. I would love to work together to best help our constituents, but something tells me they’d rather tweet than talk.

The health and safety of our community are paramount. Any threat to our environment is a threat to our well-being in the 4th Congressional District.

Our land and water are not just natural resources; they are the lifeblood of our district—supporting agriculture, recreation, and the daily needs of our residents. Protecting these vital assets is essential for our current and future generations.

Our district office is actively monitoring this situation. We are in close communication with state and county leaders to gather all pertinent information and ensure a coordinated response. We are committed to staying on top of this issue, advocating for thorough investigations, and holding any parties responsible for environmental harm accountable.

We will continue to provide updates as more information becomes available and will work tirelessly to safeguard the health of our community and the integrity of our environment.

Congressman Mark Alford
Missouri 4th District

5/ We’re committed to restoring regular order—a transparent, deliberate process where your tax dollars are allocated responsibly. It’s about accountability, efficiency, and ensuring the government works for you.

Stay tuned as we fight for fiscal sanity and more transparency in every spending decision.

4/ The goal is simple: pass all 12 bills individually to ensure the government runs efficiently and responsibly. Unfortunately, that hasn’t always been the case in recent years, and Congress has relied too often on last-minute, massive funding packages.

3/ Once on the floor, every member of the House debates and votes. If passed, the bill moves to the Senate for their consideration. After both chambers agree on a final version, it heads to the President's desk for signature.
2/ Each subcommittee drafts a bill specific to its jurisdiction. After hearings and markups, the full Appropriations Committee reviews and votes to send the bill to the House floor.

1/ The Appropriations Committee is divided into 12 subcommittees, each responsible for crafting specific spending bills that fund every corner of the federal government. Here’s the lineup:

→ Agriculture, Rural Development, FDA: Funds programs supporting farmers, rural communities, and food safety.

→ Commerce, Justice, Science: Funds law enforcement, scientific research, and economic programs.

→ Defense: Oversees funding for our military and national security.

→ Energy and Water Development: Supports energy projects and water infrastructure.

→ Financial Services: Funds the Treasury, IRS, and small business programs.

→ Homeland Security: Ensures our borders and homeland remain secure.

→ Interior and Environment: Manages public lands and environmental protection.

→ Labor, Health and Human Services, Education: Covers critical health, labor, and education initiatives.

→ Legislative Branch: Funds the operations of Congress.

→ Military Construction and Veterans Affairs: Supports military bases and veterans' programs.

→ State and Foreign Operations: Directs foreign aid and diplomatic efforts.

→ Transportation and Housing: Invests in roads, airports, and affordable housing.

🚨 I’m proud to serve on the House Appropriations Committee for the 119th Congress.

This critical committee holds a constitutional responsibility: to fund the federal government.

We want to take a moment to explain how the appropriations process works. 🧵⬇️

In this episode of Mark Alford's America, Congressman Mark Alford sits down with Missouri’s 57th Governor, Mike Parson, at his Kansas City office. Governor Parson reflects on a lifetime of service, from his days in the U.S. Army to serving as Polk County Sheriff, and his path to the Governor’s office.

He shares insights on the values driving his leadership, his commitment to Missouri’s infrastructure and workforce development, and his dedication to creating opportunities for future generations. Governor Parson also shares the inside story of how he found out he would become governor and what those first few days were like. 

Tune in for an inspiring conversation with@GovParsonMO!

I was saddened to hear the news today of the passing of President Jimmy Carter at the age of 100. President Carter led an extraordinary life, rising from humble beginnings in Plains, Georgia, to serve as the 39th President of the United States.

After leaving office, President Carter's commitment to service grew even stronger. His humanitarian work with organizations like Habitat for Humanity, where he personally helped build homes for families in need, brought hope and shelter to countless Americans; and his efforts to help ensure integrity to democratic nations, left a positive impact on the world.

President Carter’s life was deeply rooted in his faith in Jesus Christ, which he shared openly by teaching Sunday school into his later years. He was a loyal husband, a dedicated family man, and a servant leader who inspired others through his actions. His faith, compassion, and tireless dedication to service have left an indelible mark on our nation’s history. May he rest in peace.

E59: Leaving the USSR: Andrei Kulikov on Chernobyl, Freedom, and the American Spirit

(01:04) Growing Up in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR)
(03:04) Serving in the USSR Army & the Chernobyl Disaster
(08:17) Why Did Andrei Leave the USSR?
(10:25) How Did Andrei End Up in Israel?
(12:49) Living in Israel
(13:38) Becoming a United States Citizen
(15:24) Thoughts: Mass Illegal Immigration in 2024
(16:43) Thoughts: Russian invasion of Ukraine
++ much more!

Andrei Kulikov, a former Soviet soldier and now proud U.S. citizen, shares his incredible journey from the USSR to America. He was stationed at Chernobyl shortly after the 1986 nuclear disaster, witnessing the chaos and secrecy surrounding the event. Disillusioned with the Soviet regime, Andrei left in 1989, eventually finding refuge in Israel before making his way to the United States. He speaks passionately about his love for America, admiring the country’s freedom and its remarkable resilience in the face of challenges. Andrei’s story is a testament to courage and the pursuit of a better life, offering a perspective lens on the values that define America.
